text: the following report contains flash
photography night time in the southern
Chinese city of Shenzhen those with
money and energy to burn are out to play
with a secret camera we recorded young
men inhaling ketamine a drug that's
soaring in popularity here users say
ketamine makes them feel like they can
fly but many can't handle the
consequences this rehabilitation clinic
has seen a leap in the numbers
struggling with ketamine
[Applause]
just three weeks before this former
police officer couldn't function without
it the craving was really strong every
morning I wanted to snort ketamine at
night the drug kept me out it totally
screwed up my life many experienced
lasting damage to their brains and also
their bladders some have had to have
their bladders removed a heavy price to
pay we wanted to know who was profiting
ketamine can be made almost anywhere but
there's one village in China that's
notorious for making all kinds of
narcotics for sure this village made
headlines when three thousand
paramilitary police swept for sure
arresting 182 people but the drug trade
lives on despite repeated raids
we wanted to see the village for
ourselves but it's a risky trip streets
strewn with rubbish rising above them
washers millionaire row thought to be
financed with drug money the land is
polluted littered with byproducts of
drug production ketamine is technically
difficult to make but Chinese drug gangs
cracked the code now underground labs
manufacture large batches of cheap
ketamine meeting in an abandoned factory
this villager tells us the drug trade
will continue in the shadows he insists
he is not involved in actually making
drugs but many of his relatives have
been arrested for you know drug prices
are dropping because they are easier to
make too many know how to manufacture
them ketamine's becoming a significant
illegal export sixty percent of the
world's ketamine seizures take place on
the narrow boundary between mainland
China and Hong Kong unless the Chinese
authorities crack down on this drug many
worry it will spread even further beyond
China's borders Celia Hatton BBC News
Guangdong
